awd_titl_txt: CAREER: SusChEM: Metal-Metal Bonds as Active Sites in Catalysis
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project supported by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Christopher Uyeda of the Department of Chemistry at Purdue University studies molecular transition metal catalysts containing dinuclear active sites. In nature highly complex systems that contain two or more metals carry out electron transfer transformations that are central to biosynthesis and energy management. In contrast, molecular catalysts that are currently used to promote related reactions have comparatively simple structures, most commonly containing just a single metal center. This single metal must mediate all of the bond-breaking and forming events. In principle, new classes of catalysts that contain multiple metals could exhibit metal cooperativity as seen in the naturally occurring systems. These could exhibit unique properties as compared to their more well-established mononuclear counterparts. This research aims to develop the fundamental principles underlying the design of robust and efficient synthetic multinuclear catalysts. The project also contains an educational component that will introduce high school and beginning undergraduate students to catalysis research. Providing such research opportunities at Purdue positively impacts the engagement of high school students in cutting-edge research. 

This research focuses on the development of new redox-active ligand architectures that support metal-metal bonds of defined composition. By capitalizing on ligand-centered redox couples, the resulting dinuclear complexes are capable of engaging organic substrates in many of the elementary two-electron processes (e.g. oxidative additions and reductive eliminations) that form the basis for catalytic transformations. An overarching goal of this project is to connect the electronic features of metal-metal bonds to their activity and selectivity in catalysis. As such, detailed mechanistic insights into these systems are sought by (1) developing electronic structure models through a combination of experiment and theory, (2) characterizing plausible catalytic intermediates, (3) studying catalytic processes using reaction kinetics and other physical organic techniques, and (4) conducting well-controlled comparative studies between mononuclear and dinuclear catalysts. These activities are integrated with an educational component that focuses on providing opportunities for young students, including local high school students, to engage in the catalysis research being carried out in university labs.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Transition metal catalysis plays a central role in improving the efficiency and sustainability of chemical synthesis. Most of the homogeneous transition metal catalysts in current use contain only one metal in their active site. However, there is evidence to suggest that complexes containing multiple metals may exhibit unique catalytic properties due to their ability to cooperatively engage substrates. The overarching goal of this NSF CAREER award project is to rationally investigate catalytic processes at metal-metal bonds. These studies yielded fundamental insights into the organometallic chemistry of multimetallic systems and enabled the development of new transformations. The reactions that were discovered in this project are relevant to the synthesis of fine chemicals, agrochemicals, pharmaceutical compounds, and conductive materials.

Dinickel catalysts were shown to promote challenging bond activations that are not known with monometallic catalysts. For example, norbornadiene, which is a readily available commodity hydrocarbon, undergoes ring-opening by carbon-carbon oxidative addition. Addition of carbon monoxide results in the formation of a complex bicyclic framework that can serve as a useful building block for biologically active compounds. Dinickel catalysts can also promote unusual bond formations. Aryl azides undergo rapid dimerization to generate N=N double bonds. This reaction was used to prepare azoarenes, which are an important class of photoswitching compounds.

The research activities in this project were highly integrated with the engagement, education, and mentorship of students. Results were communicated through a series of peer-reviewed manuscripts and seminars presented at university seminars and conferences. Undergraduate and graduate students received extensive training in inorganic and organic chemistry, preparing them for a broad range of STEM careers. High school students had the opportunity to carry out science fair projects related to catalysis. The PI was involved mentoring students from underrepresented groups as part of a college-wide effort to promote retention and excellence.


Last Modified: 07/23/2021
Modified by: Christopher Uyeda
